statement: The idea of leveraging graphlets and orbits as units for interpretation is interesting.
The assumption that both instance-level and model-level explanations depend on graphlets (orbit bases) needs justification, as it is unclear why graphlets are important or human interpretable.
The assumption that model-level explanation should be a linear combination of orbit bases lacks justification, as the model-explanation might depend on completely different factors.
The method seems to be restricted to only node classification and it is unclear how it will generalize to other tasks such as graph classification.
Using only synthetic data for the model-level explanations needs justification, as it is unclear if such explanations make sense on real-world datasets.
The research plan aims to provide human interpretable explanations but includes no experiments asking human evaluators to evaluate the quality of the explanations.

The model-level explanation decomposition into orbit bases will potentially lose contextual information between graphlets, as these bases only capture local information and might miss broader contextual patterns in the graph.
The motivation for decomposing prediction values of target nodes into orbit units for instance-level explanation is not clearly introduced in the research plan.

The proposed method's efficiency is concerning as generating instance-level explanations requires going through all graphlets that include all 0-72 orbits, making this search method too expensive to extend to large-scale graphs.

The method's reliance on all subgraphs with up to 5 nodes as explanation units does not inherently ensure meaningful or domain-relevant structures compared to subgraph-based methods that use constraints like connectivity.

The approach does not consider node features or types, making it difficult to distinguish substructures with different real-world meanings, such as C-C and CO substructures that correspond to the same graphlet.
The research plan lacks clear explanation of what orbits in graphlets are, why orbits are used as explanation units, and what advantages graphlets and orbits have compared to existing methods.
The method is limited to using orbits from 2-5 node graphlets, restricting explanation patterns and potentially missing important patterns involving larger graphlets.

The approach requires predefining graphlets/orbits rather than learning them from data, and it is unclear whether the base set of graphlets could be extended to dynamically discover larger, more meaningful graphlets.
